subject: ICT
objectives: By the end of the lesson, students will be able to identify input and output devices and explain their functions.
materials: Pictures of computer parts, real devices (keyboard, mouse, speakers)
introduction: Elicit from learners devices they have used on a computer and what they used them for.
activities: 1) Display images and real devices. 2) Learners classify as input or output. 3) Groups present findings.
conclusion: Summarize differences between input and output devices with examples from class.
assessment: Learners list three input and three output devices with one function each.
homework: Draw and label two input and two output devices.

subject: Mathematics
objectives: Pupils will identify and generate equivalent fractions using visual and numerical methods.
materials: Fraction circles, number line, chart paper
introduction: Review numerator and denominator with fraction circles.
activities: 1) Demonstrate equivalence using folding/partitioning. 2) Simplify to lowest terms. 3) Pair practice.
conclusion: Exit ticket: write two fractions equivalent to 2/3 and explain.
assessment: Worksheet on visual models and numeric equivalence.
homework: Find three equivalents for 3/4 and draw simple models.

subject: Science
objectives: Pupils will name and describe parts of a plant and state their functions.
introduction: Show a real plant and ask learners to identify visible parts.
activities: 1) Discuss functions of roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruits. 2) Group worksheet to match part to function. 3) Observe and label a plant.
conclusion: Recap key functions; learners explain one part to class.
assessment: Label diagram and match parts to functions; oral questions.
homework: Draw and label a plant; write one function per part.
